thread.title: The biggest issue plaguing veteran Bomber
thread.title_full: The biggest issue plaguing veteran Bomber

title: The biggest issue plaguing veteran Bomber
text:
Brendon Goddard must find position and cement spot in Essendon 22, says Nick Dal Santo Staff Writers, FOX SPORTS March 1, 2017 10:31am IT’S the asset that has defined his AFL career, but an ex-teammate believes Brendon Goddard’s biggest strength could turn into a career-defining weakness this year. 
Former St Kilda and North Melbourne midfielder Nick Dal Santo says it’s difficult to see where ex-teammate Goddard fits in at Essendon on the field this year, with so many players returning to the club. 
Goddard captained the Bombers and lead the midfield group last year in the absence of Jobe Watson and Dyson Heppell, who were one of 34 past and present Bombers players serving 12-month bans. 
During his prime years at the Saints at the start of the decade, Goddard was one of the competition’s best utilities, with the ability to play anywhere on the ground making him a dangerous weapon for then-coach Ross Lyon. 
But former St Kilda teammate Dal Santo said Goddard needed to lock down a firm position to secure his spot at Essendon, otherwise it could leave the veteran hanging. 
“I don’t know where that fits in to the Essendon team at the moment,” Dal Santo said on Fox Sports News’ AFL Tonight on Tuesday. media_camera Brendon Goddard is still in Essendon’s leadership group. Picture: Michael Klein 
“When you’ve got the likes of a Heppell, a Watson, the guys that play the majority in the midfield, you’ve got young Zach Merrett coming through — I’m not sure where BJ fits into that side right now. 
“I don’t know how long he can play for if he’s constantly getting moved around. 
“I’m not concerned because he is a quality player and a quality person. But yes, I think he needs to find a position that is his again.” 
Dal Santo said he watched the Bombers take on Collingwood in the first JLT Community Series game of the season and noticed Goddard was “getting moved around a little bit”. 
“He’s an amazing player, his greatest asset over the years — one has been his skill level, which means he can play in multiple positions,” Dal Santo said. 
“But he does play in multiple positions, he’s been able to fill those gaps — we used to call him Selleys ... because he’d just fill in wherever you needed him.”
